verses.text: O LORD, God of my salvation, I have cried out to you by day and at night before you.
verses.comment: The psalmist addresses God with the title 'God of my salvation,' showing his hope amid despair—a pattern echoed in liturgical prayers throughout Israel and the Church.

verses.text: Let my prayer come before you; incline your ear to my cry.
verses.comment: The psalmist asks God to hear his plea, stressing persistence in prayer, akin to the intercessory devotion practiced in all generations of the faithful.

verses.text: For my soul is filled with troubles, and my life draws near to Sheol.
verses.comment: The psalmist's distress is so great that he feels on the verge of death—‘Sheol’ meaning the realm of the dead in Hebrew thought.

verses.text: I am counted among those who go down to the pit; I am like a man without strength,
verses.comment: Being ‘counted among those who go down to the pit’ echoes the human experience of spiritual and existential despair, yet the language points toward the hope of the Resurrection.

verses.text: set apart among the dead, like the slain who lie in the grave, whom you remember no more, for they are cut off from your hand.
verses.comment: Old Testament understanding of death is reflected here—as separation from God’s covenant presence, which contrasts with Christian hope in Christ’s victory over death (1 Cor. 15:54).

verses.text: You have put me in the lowest pit, in the darkest depths.
verses.comment: The psalmist attributes his suffering to the sovereignty of God—a theme developed later in the Church’s teaching on redemptive suffering.

verses.text: Your wrath lies heavily upon me, and you have afflicted me with all your waves. Selah.
verses.comment: The mention of 'Selah' suggests a pause for meditation—theologically, this evokes reflection on God’s mysterious providence (cf. Rom. 11:33).

verses.text: You have taken my closest friends from me; you have made me repulsive to them. I am confined and cannot escape.
verses.comment: Alienation from friends and isolation recalls Christ’s abandonment in Gethsemane (Matt. 26:56), foreshadowing his redemptive suffering.

verses.text: My eyes grow dim through sorrow. Every day I call upon you, O LORD; I spread out my hands to you.
verses.comment: The posture of prayer described here anticipates Christian liturgical gestures, such as the Orans position, common in early Christian worship.

verses.text: Do you work wonders for the dead? Do the departed rise up to praise you? Selah.
verses.comment: The psalmist’s question hints at the hope of the Resurrection; early Christians read such verses as foreshadowing Christ’s victory over death.

verses.text: Is your steadfast love declared in the grave, or your faithfulness in Abaddon?
verses.comment: 'Abaddon' means destruction—here, the psalmist laments God seems absent after death, showing the need for the incarnate Savior who brings hope even in Sheol.

verses.text: Are your wonders known in the darkness, or your righteousness in the land of forgetfulness?
verses.comment: ‘Land of forgetfulness’ shows the bleakness of Sheol; Christian tradition sees Christ as the Light entering humanity’s deepest darkness.

verses.text: But I, O LORD, cry to you; in the morning my prayer comes before you.
verses.comment: Perseverance in prayer even in suffering prefigures the Christian call to ceaseless prayer (1 Thess. 5:17), as seen in monastic and liturgical traditions.

verses.text: O LORD, why do you cast off my soul? Why do you hide your face from me?
verses.comment: This cry echoes Jesus’ words on the Cross (Matt. 27:46), underscoring that God’s apparent absence is not abandonment, but part of His salvific plan.

verses.text: Afflicted and close to death from my youth up, I have borne your terrors; I am helpless.
verses.comment: The enduring nature of the psalmist’s suffering highlights the mystery of suffering—explored profoundly in Catholic spiritual writers.

verses.text: Your wrath has swept over me; your terrors have destroyed me.
verses.comment: Experiencing God’s 'wrath' can mean the consequences of sin or spiritual purification—a theme later expanded in Church doctrine about purgation and redemptive suffering.

verses.text: They surround me like water all day long; they close in on me together.
verses.comment: The flood imagery prefigures the overwhelming trials endured by Christ, who sanctifies all human suffering through his Passion.

verses.text: You have taken from me friend and beloved; my companions are now darkness.
verses.comment: The Psalm ends at a low point, unique among the psalms. Even so, the sense of forsakenness is mirrored in Christ’s passion, and in the Church’s doctrine it is precisely in darkness that faith clings to God’s presence in the sacraments, especially the Eucharist.
